abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Health Sector
            Reform Project in Kyrgyz Republic were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned
            included: 1) Sound quality at entry is critical; design must
            be supported by solid analytical work; piloting smaller
            scale operations and reforms can help build capacity and
            stakeholder support; 2) Strong Government ownership is not
            sufficient, it must be backed up with resources and budget
            execution must be synchronized with health reforms; 3)
            Explicit assessment of political risks could provide
            guidance to teams embarking on projects that support
            reforms; 4) A lesson on how to undertake health sector
            reforms is that sometimes complex designs are necessary and
            a broader approach could be the only way to achieve the
            expected outcomes. This means that within the Bank, teams
            from different sectors need better coordination that would
            allow for full use of instruments and within a country
            better alignment of frameworks is a must; 5) In a developing
            sector supported by a large number of donors; successful
            donor coordination is critical for successful comprehensive
            reforms and; 6) When health reforms change the role of the
            Ministry of Health (MOH) to one of stewardship, focus must
            also be on institutional development and governance. As a
            steward of health care, more transparency and accountability
            become expected. This means that MOH and the sector as a
            whole need stronger and transparent fiduciary function
            (procurement, financial management).
